Teacher's Work Doubled by Non-co-operative Parents.--The neglect of parents to train their children makes the work of the teacher doubly hard. The children 
                                                                           327
bear the stamp of the unruly, unamiable traits revealed by their parents. Neglected at home, they regard the discipline of the school as oppressive and severe. Such children, if not carefully guarded, will leaven other children by their undisciplined, deformed characters. . . . The good that children might receive in school to counteract their defective home training is undermined by the sympathy which their parents show for them in their wrongdoing.
